docs.abstract: The Working Families Party wants to represent the resistance.
docs.snippet: The Working Families Party wants to represent the resistance.
docs.lead_paragraph: During the 20 years that he has led the social democratic Working Families Party, Dan Cantor has waited for the left to get serious about building power through local politics. “People, sophisticated people, barely know who their state senator is,” he told me. A significant portion of nonmilitary spending in America is done at the state and local levels, he pointed out, “so it’s not like these are trivial offices. This is where people live.”

docs.abstract: Officers shot a man holding an object in his hand after responding to 911 calls about a man threatening people with a gun. It was a metal pipe with a knob.
docs.snippet: Officers shot a man holding an object in his hand after responding to 911 calls about a man threatening people with a gun. It was a metal pipe with a knob.
docs.lead_paragraph: New York City police officers shot and killed a black man who was known to be mentally ill on a Brooklyn street corner on Wednesday afternoon after he pointed what the officers believed was a gun at them, the authorities said. The object, however, turned out to be a metal pipe with a knob on it.

headline.main: Police Fatally Shoot a Brooklyn Man, Saying They Thought He Had a Gun
headline.print_headline: Police in Brooklyn Kill a Man Pointing a Pipe Believed to Be a Gun

byline.original: By Benjamin Mueller and Nate Schweber

docs.abstract: When the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was assassinated, public perception of him was more mixed than it is today. Readers recount the mood they witnessed 50 years ago.
docs.snippet: When the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was assassinated, public perception of him was more mixed than it is today. Readers recount the mood they witnessed 50 years ago.
docs.lead_paragraph: For many years, the United States has lived under a broad consensus that the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. is a national hero, even a national saint. But nearly a half-century ago, when he was assassinated, public perception of him was far more mixed. Near the end of his life, only a third of the public viewed him positively, according to a 1966 Gallup poll.

headline.main: ‘Glee, Satisfaction and Weeping’: How America Reacted When Martin Luther King Died

docs.abstract: More than a month after the network pulled a charged episode of his show, the producer is looking to leave for Netflix, people familiar with negotiations said.
docs.snippet: More than a month after the network pulled a charged episode of his show, the producer is looking to leave for Netflix, people familiar with negotiations said.
docs.lead_paragraph: Kenya Barris, the A-list writer-producer behind the ABC comedy “black-ish,” has grown frustrated with his home network and is examining the possibility of making an early exit from his contract, according to three people familiar with the negotiations.

headline.main: Kenya Barris, Creator of ‘Black-ish,’ Is Said to Seek an Exit From ABC
headline.print_headline: Creator of ‘Black-ish’ Is Said to Seek Early Exit From ABC

byline.original: By John Koblin and Brooks Barnes

docs.abstract: The civil rights leader answered questions about his experience in the struggle for equal rights and the current state of the nation.
docs.snippet: The civil rights leader answered questions about his experience in the struggle for equal rights and the current state of the nation.
docs.lead_paragraph: In an Op-Ed article this week, the Rev. Jesse Jackson wrote about the need to remember the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. as a radical, ecumenical, antiwar, pro-immigrant and scholarly champion of the poor. Readers shared their own reminiscences about Dr. King and their thoughts on the changes in the country since his assassination 50 years ago. Here are some of their comments and Mr. Jackson’s responses. — The Editors

headline.main: Jesse Jackson on Race Relations, Trump and the Right to Vote

docs.abstract: “Power to the People” at the Schirn Kunsthalle Frankfurt focuses on the universal subject of politics in art, rather than on the political issues themselves.
docs.snippet: “Power to the People” at the Schirn Kunsthalle Frankfurt focuses on the universal subject of politics in art, rather than on the political issues themselves.
docs.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — A sea of 100 multicolored banners in the atrium of the Schirn Kunsthalle here, roughly assembled using plywood, fabric and adhesive tape, provides the first indication that this art gallery is in protest mode. The 2015 installation by the British artist Phyllida Barlow is a pertinent symbol of our turbulent times — an epoch of #MeToo, Black Lives Matter, marches for women and in defense of science, and demonstrations against gun violence.

headline.main: Protesting Artists Step Off the Streets and Into the Gallery

docs.abstract: New organizations are forming and succeeding in an age of distrust.
docs.snippet: New organizations are forming and succeeding in an age of distrust.
docs.lead_paragraph: Once upon a time, power was held in the hands of a small elite. This elite occupied the commanding heights of society and controlled big, top-down organizations. It dropped products and messages from on high, and the rest of us passively consumed them.

keywords.name: creative_works
keywords.value: New Power: How Businesses Thrive, Movements Begin, and Ideas Catch Fire in Our Highly Connected World (Book)

headline.main: Jackson, Macron, Golden State Killer: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing

byline.original: By Karen Zraick and Sandra Stevenson

docs.abstract: A polarizing Republican in the White House. Protests for equality in the streets. A new wave of sexual self-identification. Welcome to the 36 months when the city changed forever.
docs.snippet: A polarizing Republican in the White House. Protests for equality in the streets. A new wave of sexual self-identification. Welcome to the 36 months when the city changed forever.
docs.lead_paragraph: A polarizing Republican in the White House. Protests for equality in the streets. A new wave of sexual self-identification. This was N.Y.C. in the early ’80s, during the 36 months in which it changed art, design, activism, food, literature and love — forever.

headline.main: Why Early ’80s New York Matters Today

docs.abstract: Ramon and Audrey take some time off from their respective forms of martyrdom.
docs.snippet: Ramon and Audrey take some time off from their respective forms of martyrdom.
docs.lead_paragraph: Finally, Duc Bayer-Boatwright gets his moment in the sun. Don’t get too excited; it’s not that he has a psychological breakthrough or stops being a jerk or even has a particularly substantial story line in this week’s episode of “Here and Now.” For the second week in a row, he’s gritting his teeth through a colitis flare-up — and Ramon’s poop jokes aren’t helping. Duc’s big scene takes place during a hike with his love interest, Carmen. Doubled over in pain, he gets so frantic about finding a place to relieve himself that he falls down a hill and exits the date in an ambulance.

headline.main: ‘Here and Now’ Season 1, Episode 8: The Absurdist Hero
